Hopkins whitewashed the infant
Loyola swimming team as completely as: it could be done Friday
night, emerging from the K. of C.
pool with a second one:sided victory to its credit. None of the
Evergreen slyininters beat a Hopkins man, or even:came close to it.
The spectators stretched their
necks to see which of the two Jay
competitors in each event would
reach the finish first, and then,
after clapping, waited for the Loyola entries to finish.

This school being up in the hills,
with a wonderful playing field,
a swimming pool and very comfortable sleeping quarters, makes
an ideal spot in which to train
men. The only trouble last year
was that the school management
insisted on feeding the boys too
much and made them all lazy.
Norman G. Keyes, Graduate
Manager, has recently been appointed a member of the National
Advisory Board of the Football
Rules Committee.

Dr. John B. Whitehead, Dean
of the Engineering School, has
been signally honored by receiving the appointment of French
Exchange Professor for the year
of 1927. He has been granted a
leave of absence from January 1
to October 1 of that year, so that
he may deliver a series of lectures chiefly on insulation and
dielectric theories at French universities.
This
distinguished
Johns Hopkins scientist is the
fifth engineer to represent the
United States in •the annual exchange of professors with the
most renowned in France.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 9, 1926;

THE AUTOCRAT
Our soul is filled with misery, our mind is filled with questionings. Is it possible that one cannot criticize the campus
powers, cannot offer suggestions to the Student Council?
Several weeks ago the columns of this paper were filled
ivith much jabbering, about •the burning issue. ,of unlimited
cuts. in a moment of forgetfulness we suggested that the
Student Council act one way or the other on the question.
Lo and behold, 3Ir. Alger Hiss, President of the Student Council, writes .to the editor, telling him that his personal opinion
Should have no consideration—(even in a small suggestion)—
that in order to bring the matter before the Council one of the
'classes would just have to instruct its delegates to that effect.
Now the editor of the NEWS-LETTER admittedly has no
voiee in campus affairs. But, dropping the mantel of office,
ettnnot any individual offer suggestions? Will the Student
Council refuse to act upon them unless the classes first endorse the suggestion?
•
It seems to us that any student should have, as a matter
of course, the right to make suggestions to the governing body
without the necessity of a formal class vote. Then, naturally,
the Council could approve or'drop the suggestion; but it should
• give it consideration first.
This outburst is not in defense of our little idea; it seems.
to us that the Council is establishing a dangerous precedent;
followed to its logical conclusion it would establish a campus
autocrat:—so we protest.

A GOOD MOVE
After the recent demise of anothe&r of the useless campus
organizations comes the even more cheerful news that a really
• worthwhile club is being planned.
The proposed activities club, suggested no doubt by the
Athletic Varsity Club, meets the traditional and ancestral '"long
'felt need on the campus." The plan seems to have everything
-in its favor and nothing against it. Such an organization without the annoyances of dues and frequent meetings at set intervals, would nevertheless have, a most helpful influence on the
campus non-athletic activities.
We may be unduly optimistic, but an activities club, in'
• um- opinion, would be the best rallying point of Alumni interest
and support yet devised. The class is at best unwieldly as any
alumni unit, with a few outstanding men and with the rank and
file bound by no significant common interest. But men who
have risen to leadership in campus activities will form a very
different body. A man will not soon forget an activity to
which he has devoted four years of work, nor w,ill he soon lose
interest in the scene of his activities, the campus. A club of
these men would not need the stimulus'of an elaborate organ/ation.or of a present definite aim. The interest and comrad-•
,hip which already exist will hold it together much more effectively. And these men, while grouped around the festive board,
,could, in the intervals between their reminisences of the old
.days, give some pretty good suggestions to undergraduate activities.
The plan for such a club seems sound from the ground up;
‘the NEWS-LETTER favors it.
J. H. J.

SPECIAL RATES FOR HOPKINS STUDENTS

•
Pride—The emotion felt concerning certain thoughts and
actions of which we are barely conscious—until we look back
on the ones we prefer to remember.
Print—The philosopher stone which transmutes personal
tastes into papal bulls.
Student Opinion—An entity so vague and uncertain that
even the President of the Student Council seems to doubt its
existence.
Student Self-Government—A toy whose wheels go round
on the impetus imparted by the profound thought that spanking one's self saves somebody else that trouble.
Theology—A game in which it is very poor sportsmanship
to ask about the origin of the God who was designed to explain
all other origins.
Tolerance—The feeling that only I could have done it
better.
*
Apropos of nothing, we are printing the following contribution which sprang fully armed from the troubled soul of' a
Senior. He declares that he dashed it off, don't you know, in a
moment of fevered cogitation, and strictly without malice pretense. Personally, we are inclined to respect his plea of extenuating circumstances; namely, that he majored in a curious study
known as Philosophy.

-A swirling whirlpool of sorrow intermingled with
joy.
'
As I am swept onward and around in my petty (though
alarmingly vivid and real to me) vicissitudes of daily life, I
am visibly affected and hourly impressed by the baleful sight
of the yawning vortex as many years away .as chance shall
•direct. I am as a chip in the frothing*waters, and my companion chips as they cross and recross my devious path affect
me only as, they may alter my uncertain course by a mere
touch of the microscopic wakes caused by their insignificant
passage near me. Ofttimes one chip will strike me gently and
cling to me by the force of attraction for a distance, often only
to be cast aside as a gust of spray deflects its wavering drift.
Onward, ever onward—to satisfy a whim.
• I was thrown into the pool; I am a helpless victim and
must drift, aimlessly drift, ieceiving grief and happiness alike
until my fruitless voyage is culminated,—perhaps by a downward current hurrying me to the rotating water-hole by a short
cut, perhaps by a longer route. At all events, my terminus is
the same. If I float easily, I am happy; perhaps I may float
more easily with another chip clinging fast to my side. When
I have drifted a little longer, I may read a purpose in the
surging waves, but I am dubious.
However,—Who can tell?"
(L. I). S.)

The little fellow was staring

to escape when he was taken out

But once released, the opossum
refused to *budge until nightfall,
Nvhen he regained his confidence
with his sight and scampered off
into the woods, with thrilling
news for'the family.
For four years bird trapping
has been going on at Hopkins and
a variety of four-legged animals
have been caught, such as rats,
flying squirrels, chipmunks, and
even cats. But this is the first
time on record, according to the
zoology department, that the bird
trap ever held an opossum prisoiler.

Two Illustrations

3:00 P.M.—Barnstormers' Rehearsal.

Mr. Wilson, who has spoken to

over two hundred thousand college men, began his talk by a brief
discussion of the fact that far
more than half of the graduates
.of Johns Hopkins would be more
or less directly connected with
education in the future, whether
as teachers, authors, lawyers or
in other walks of life. He then,
"to make a short cut," took an
illustration from the science of
mathematics, and one from grammar. In his first he showed that
a definition of a solid was not
complete without three terms; in
his second , he demonstrated the
importance of punctuation in
making a definition clear.
Two Dimensions

Using blackboard diagrams, Mr.
Wilson proceeded to develop a
three dimensional definition of
man. "In the first place," he
said, "man is one dimensional;
he is bones, blood, nerves, and
glands. The wastebasket of the
world is full of nations who have
accepted this physical-chemical
definition. Dealt with constructively, the body is a wonderful
thing—but life is more than eating, drinking, making money, and
then good-night nurse."
"Man is two dimensional; he
is a knowing being," Mr. Wilson
continued, "for he has a marvelous 'ability of approaching and
unraveling for his own utility
the facts of the universe." Under
this head were included memory,
books, and constructive imagination.
Stresses Third

-Man is three dimensional; he
has the ability to estimate values."
Ideals, a conception of the ends
of life, the idea of objectives, and
the conception of purposes were
included by Mr. Wilson in this
definition. At this third dimension only, he stated, was he willing to put a period, for it rounded out the definition of man.
"If your education is neglected
in the third dimension," concluded
Mr. Wilson, -it is your loss and
the world is cheated also, and it
is this phase that is being neglected. You are never educated
unless you have accented the third
syllable--the syllable of ideals, of
values, and of great ultimate
purpose."

Robinson, McNeal, . Farinholt
and Ward were nominated for the
Vice-Presidency of the junior class
at a meeting held, last Friday.
When President Harwood left the
University, Vice-President Lord
assumed the duties Of the president, thus leaving the office of
Vice-President vacant.
The banquet committee has set
Friday evening, April 30, as the
time for the banquet. • The nature
of the entertainment has not been
decided upon. The junior banquet
will mark the opening of the freshman-sophothore banquet season.'
Work has been apportioned
among the members of .the June
Week Committee. At present the
committee is looking for novelties
suitable for the 1927 June Week.
An amendment to Article IV,
Section 5 of the ConstitutiOn, was
introduced and placed on the table
by Secretary Jarrett. As it now
stands, Section 5 states that, "In
case no candidate shall receive a
majority vote of the entire class,
the two candidates receiving the
highest number of votes shall be
voted. on again at a meeting held
in not more than a week's time."
Under the proposed amendment,
"the majority vote of -the entire
class" is changed to "the majority
vote of a quorum."
The,. candidates for Vice-President and the proposed amendment
will he voted on at the meeting to
be held Friday.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., MARCH 9, 1926;

THE AUTOCRAT
Our soul is filled with misery, our mind is filled with questionings. Is it possible that one cannot criticize the campus
powers, cannot offer suggestions to the Student Council?
Several weeks ago the columns of this paper were filled
ivith much jabbering, about •the burning issue. ,of unlimited
cuts. in a moment of forgetfulness we suggested that the
Student Council act one way or the other on the question.
Lo and behold, 3Ir. Alger Hiss, President of the Student Council, writes .to the editor, telling him that his personal opinion
Should have no consideration—(even in a small suggestion)—
that in order to bring the matter before the Council one of the
'classes would just have to instruct its delegates to that effect.
Now the editor of the NEWS-LETTER admittedly has no
voiee in campus affairs. But, dropping the mantel of office,
ettnnot any individual offer suggestions? Will the Student
Council refuse to act upon them unless the classes first endorse the suggestion?
•
It seems to us that any student should have, as a matter
of course, the right to make suggestions to the governing body
without the necessity of a formal class vote. Then, naturally,
the Council could approve or'drop the suggestion; but it should
• give it consideration first.
This outburst is not in defense of our little idea; it seems.
to us that the Council is establishing a dangerous precedent;
followed to its logical conclusion it would establish a campus
autocrat:—so we protest.

A GOOD MOVE
After the recent demise of anothe&r of the useless campus
organizations comes the even more cheerful news that a really
• worthwhile club is being planned.
The proposed activities club, suggested no doubt by the
Athletic Varsity Club, meets the traditional and ancestral '"long
'felt need on the campus." The plan seems to have everything
-in its favor and nothing against it. Such an organization without the annoyances of dues and frequent meetings at set intervals, would nevertheless have, a most helpful influence on the
campus non-athletic activities.
We may be unduly optimistic, but an activities club, in'
• um- opinion, would be the best rallying point of Alumni interest
and support yet devised. The class is at best unwieldly as any
alumni unit, with a few outstanding men and with the rank and
file bound by no significant common interest. But men who
have risen to leadership in campus activities will form a very
different body. A man will not soon forget an activity to
which he has devoted four years of work, nor w,ill he soon lose
interest in the scene of his activities, the campus. A club of
these men would not need the stimulus'of an elaborate organ/ation.or of a present definite aim. The interest and comrad-•
,hip which already exist will hold it together much more effectively. And these men, while grouped around the festive board,
,could, in the intervals between their reminisences of the old
.days, give some pretty good suggestions to undergraduate activities.
The plan for such a club seems sound from the ground up;
‘the NEWS-LETTER favors it.
J. H. J.

Pride—The emotion felt concerning certain thoughts and
actions of which we are barely conscious—until we look back
on the ones we prefer to remember.
Print—The philosopher stone which transmutes personal
tastes into papal bulls.
Student Opinion—An entity so vague and uncertain that
even the President of the Student Council seems to doubt its
existence.
Student Self-Government—A toy whose wheels go round
on the impetus imparted by the profound thought that spanking one's self saves somebody else that trouble.
Theology—A game in which it is very poor sportsmanship
to ask about the origin of the God who was designed to explain
all other origins.
Tolerance—The feeling that only I could have done it
better.

-A swirling whirlpool of sorrow intermingled with
joy.
'
As I am swept onward and around in my petty (though
alarmingly vivid and real to me) vicissitudes of daily life, I
am visibly affected and hourly impressed by the baleful sight
of the yawning vortex as many years away .as chance shall
•direct. I am as a chip in the frothing*waters, and my companion chips as they cross and recross my devious path affect
me only as, they may alter my uncertain course by a mere
touch of the microscopic wakes caused by their insignificant
passage near me. Ofttimes one chip will strike me gently and
cling to me by the force of attraction for a distance, often only
to be cast aside as a gust of spray deflects its wavering drift.
Onward, ever onward—to satisfy a whim.
• I was thrown into the pool; I am a helpless victim and
must drift, aimlessly drift, ieceiving grief and happiness alike
until my fruitless voyage is culminated,—perhaps by a downward current hurrying me to the rotating water-hole by a short
cut, perhaps by a longer route. At all events, my terminus is
the same. If I float easily, I am happy; perhaps I may float
more easily with another chip clinging fast to my side. When
I have drifted a little longer, I may read a purpose in the
surging waves, but I am dubious.
However,—Who can tell?"
(L. I). S.)

Two Illustrations

3:00 P.M.—Barnstormers' Rehearsal.

Mr. Wilson, who has spoken to

over two hundred thousand college men, began his talk by a brief
discussion of the fact that far
more than half of the graduates
.of Johns Hopkins would be more
or less directly connected with
education in the future, whether
as teachers, authors, lawyers or
in other walks of life. He then,
"to make a short cut," took an
illustration from the science of
mathematics, and one from grammar. In his first he showed that
a definition of a solid was not
complete without three terms; in
his second , he demonstrated the
importance of punctuation in
making a definition clear.
Two Dimensions

Using blackboard diagrams, Mr.
Wilson proceeded to develop a
three dimensional definition of
man. "In the first place," he
said, "man is one dimensional;
he is bones, blood, nerves, and
glands. The wastebasket of the
world is full of nations who have
accepted this physical-chemical
definition. Dealt with constructively, the body is a wonderful
thing—but life is more than eating, drinking, making money, and
then good-night nurse."
"Man is two dimensional; he
is a knowing being," Mr. Wilson
continued, "for he has a marvelous 'ability of approaching and
unraveling for his own utility
the facts of the universe." Under
this head were included memory,
books, and constructive imagination.
Stresses Third

-Man is three dimensional; he
has the ability to estimate values."
Ideals, a conception of the ends
of life, the idea of objectives, and
the conception of purposes were
included by Mr. Wilson in this
definition. At this third dimension only, he stated, was he willing to put a period, for it rounded out the definition of man.
"If your education is neglected
in the third dimension," concluded
Mr. Wilson, -it is your loss and
the world is cheated also, and it
is this phase that is being neglected. You are never educated
unless you have accented the third
syllable--the syllable of ideals, of
values, and of great ultimate
purpose."

Robinson, McNeal, . Farinholt
and Ward were nominated for the
Vice-Presidency of the junior class
at a meeting held, last Friday.
When President Harwood left the
University, Vice-President Lord
assumed the duties Of the president, thus leaving the office of
Vice-President vacant.
The banquet committee has set
Friday evening, April 30, as the
time for the banquet. • The nature
of the entertainment has not been
decided upon. The junior banquet
will mark the opening of the freshman-sophothore banquet season.'
Work has been apportioned
among the members of .the June
Week Committee. At present the
committee is looking for novelties
suitable for the 1927 June Week.
An amendment to Article IV,
Section 5 of the ConstitutiOn, was
introduced and placed on the table
by Secretary Jarrett. As it now
stands, Section 5 states that, "In
case no candidate shall receive a
majority vote of the entire class,
the two candidates receiving the
highest number of votes shall be
voted. on again at a meeting held
in not more than a week's time."
Under the proposed amendment,
"the majority vote of -the entire
class" is changed to "the majority
vote of a quorum."
The,. candidates for Vice-President and the proposed amendment
will he voted on at the meeting to
be held Friday.

A number of men have been
written to in reference to drawing a cover for this number. The
Jay will not publish their names
until the final choice is made. •
It has been announced that letters were received from'H. 1VIencken, Christopher Ward, Rudyard
Kipling and Irvin S. Cobb and
that these will be printed in the
magazine.
• The idea of a Celebrity Number
is not new with the Blue Jay but
it is thought that it has never
been carried out on such a large
or ambitious scale as the Hopkins
paper is doing at the present
time. Over two, hundred men
have been written to and about
eighty replies received up to this
date, with more coming in every
day.
The number will be released on
the night of the Barnstormer production and will be sold in the
tisles and lobby of the Lyric.
